senses.de: To produce or provide something as a result
senses.ex: The orchard can yield a substantial amount of fruit each year.

Tips.title: Result Oriented
Tips.description: Used when something leads to a result or outcome, especially in business or science contexts.
Tips.example: The research will yield new insights into climate change.

Tips.title: Active Process
Tips.description: Implies an ongoing action – something that is actively yielding results, not just once.
Tips.example: This strategy could yield benefits for years to come.

senses.de: To give up power, control or territory to someone else
senses.ex: The king was forced to yield his crown to his younger brother.

Tips.title: Power Shift
Tips.description: Describes a situation where there’s a transfer of authority, often in politics or social contexts.
Tips.example: After negotiations, the general agreed to yield command.

Tips.title: Reluctant Agreement
Tips.description: Suggests reluctant acceptance, or giving in under pressure rather than voluntary action.
Tips.example: He would not yield to their demands despite the pressure.

senses.de: The total amount produced or supplied
senses.ex: The crop's yield was significantly lower this year because of the drought.

Tips.title: Measurement Value
Tips.description: Refers to quantifying what has been produced, commonly used in agriculture and manufacturing.
Tips.example: Farmers discussed ways to increase the yield of wheat per acre.

Tips.title: Performance Indicator
Tips.description: Considered a key indicator of performance, efficiency or success in producing something.
Tips.example: Technicians celebrated the high yield of the new machine.

senses.de: To stop and allow others to move first
senses.ex: Always yield to pedestrians at the crosswalk.

Tips.title: Road Safety
Tips.description: Emphasizes the importance of safety and courtesy on the roads, often in driving instructions.
Tips.example: Yield signs at intersections help prevent accidents.

Tips.title: Right of Way
Tips.description: Reminds drivers to allow another road user to go first; often legally required in traffic.
Tips.example: You must yield the right of way to emergency vehicles.

senses.de: The amount of profit gained from an investment or treasury
senses.ex: The bond has a yield of 5 percent.

Tips.title: Financial Performance
Tips.description: Indicates profitability, especially in the context of investments or financial products.
Tips.example: Investors are looking for stocks with a steady yield.

Tips.title: Investment Priority
Tips.description: Signals the value or priority given to the return of an investment; high-yield options are sought after.
Tips.example: Her portfolio is focused on high-yield bonds.

Bear.wordDefinition:
Bear means to endure or tolerate something, or to carry the weight of something.

It can also refer to an animal with shaggy fur and sharp claws. For example, "I can't bear the thought of losing my family" or "The bear lumbered through the forest.".

These words are used in different contexts, and their meanings can't be interchanged. Bear is used when talking about withstanding something or carrying something, while yield is used when talking about giving way or producing something.

Concede.wordDefinition:
Concede means to admit defeat or to acknowledge that someone else is right.

It is typically used when someone is giving up an argument or position. For example, "I concede that you were right about the answer.".

Concede refers to admitting defeat while yield refers to backing down. The best word to use will depend on the specific situation.

Deliver.wordDefinition: Deliver means to transport or bring goods or services to a person or place. It is applicable in situations where a physical object or service needs to be brought to someone or somewhere, such as delivering a package or delivering goods to a store.

Furnish.wordDefinition:
Furnish means to provide or supply something, often furniture or equipment, that will be useful or needed.

It is usually used in relation to a physical object or item. For example, a new apartment may need to be furnished with a bed or a table.

Furnish applies to providing physical objects or equipment, while yield applies to giving up something or producing a result.

Generate.wordDefinition:
Generate means to produce, create or bring about something new, while yield means to produce or give out as a result of effort, work or pressure.

For example, a power plant generates electricity by converting fuel into energy. A fruit tree yields fruit when it is properly tended and cared for.

Generate is applicable when something new is created or produced, while yield is applicable when something is produced or given out as a result of effort or natural growth.

Give.wordDefinition:
Both give and yield mean to provide or surrender something.

However, give is generally used in instances where the action is voluntary or intentional. For example, "I gave him a book as a gift.".

Give implies a deliberate action while yield implies a more natural outcome.

Produce.wordDefinition: Produce means to create or make something. For example, a farmer produces crops, a manufacturer produces goods.

Provide.wordDefinition:
Provide means to give or supply something, usually something that is needed or requested. For example, a teacher might provide his students with books for their course.

Provide refers to actively giving or supplying something, while yield refers to something being produced as a natural or passive result.

Both words can be used in a variety of contexts and are generally interchangeable, but provide emphasizes the active role of the provider while yield emphasizes the natural outcome of a situation.

Submit.wordDefinition:
Both submit and yield mean to give in or surrender in some way, but they are used in slightly different situations.

Submit typically means to send or hand over something, like a form or an idea. For example, you might submit a job application or submit an essay to your teacher.

Submit is more often used in formal contexts (like submitting a form), while yield is used in both formal and everyday communication (like yielding to another driver on the road).

Supply.wordDefinition:
Supply means the amount of a product or service that is available for people to buy or use.

In other words, supply refers to how much of something is available, while yield refers to how much of something is produced or provided.

Surrender.wordDefinition:
Surrender means to give up completely, usually in a situation where a person or group has no choice but to stop fighting or resisting.

In simpler terms, surrender means giving up completely while yield means compromising or conceding to a certain extent.

videos.Text: Despite six months of double checking, the bizarre discovery refused to yield. But rather than celebrating a physics revolution, the researchers published a cautious paper arguing for continued research in an effort to explain the observed anomaly.

quotes.Text: We are not spending the Federal Government's money, we are spending the taxpayer's money, and it must be spent n a way which guarantees his money's worth and yields the fullest possible benefit to the people being helped.
quotes.Title: American President
quotes.Name: Richard M. Nixon

quotes.Text: Do you really think it is weakness that yields to temptation? I tell you that there are terrible temptations which it requires strength, strength and courage to yield to.
quotes.Title: Irish Poet
quotes.Name: Oscar Wilde

quotes.Text: Freedom comes only to those who no longer ask of life that it shall yield them any of those personal goods that are subject to the mutations of time.
quotes.Title: British Philosopher
quotes.Name: Bertrand Russell

quotes.Text: I think an interview, properly considered, should be an investigation. You shouldn't know what the interview will yield. Otherwise, why do it at all?
quotes.Title: American Director
quotes.Name: Errol Morris

quotes.Text: Self-pity is our worst enemy and if we yield to it, we can never do anything wise in this world.
quotes.Title: American Author
quotes.Name: Helen Keller

quotes.Text: When defeat is inevitable, it is wisest to yield.
quotes.Title: Roman Educator
quotes.Name: Quintilian

quotes.Text: My honour was not yielded, but conquered merely.
quotes.Title: Egyptian Royalty
quotes.Name: Cleopatra

quotes.Text: A shady business never yields a sunny life.
quotes.Title: Scottish Journalist
quotes.Name: B. C. Forbes

quotes.Text: Even wisdom has to yield to self-interest.
quotes.Title: Greek Poet
quotes.Name: Pindar

quotes.Text: We are free to yield to truth.
quotes.Title: Roman Poet
quotes.Name: Horace
